Package lab

The package contains the code for studying the Factory, Builder, and Prototype creational patterns.

See:
          Description

Class Summary
BoxDoor A boxdoor is a connection between two room.
Door A door is a connection between two room that can be opened or closed.
Horse Horse is an automatically moving object.
Images A Singleton Factory that creates and stores images and is used as an image repository that only has a single copy of every image loaded.
MapSite The abstract super class to everything used to build the stable.
MovingObject The abstract super class to all object that can move around in the stable.
NullSide A null side is a side of a room that does nothing.
Person Person is the moving object controlled by the user using the arrow keys.
Room A room class that holds the walls or doors.
Stable The root class of the stable.
StableApplet  
StablePanel This is the class where the students should make changes.
Wall Is class represents a wall in the stable.
 

Package lab Description

The package contains the code for studying the Factory, Builder, and Prototype creational patterns.

Introduction

In this lab, a number of walls, doors, and rooms are combined into a stable using three different creational design patterns. The class that represents the stable is called Stable. The stable is composed of a number of rooms, and each room is composed of four sides of different types/classes. Each side class is a subclass of MapSite; please refer to GoF.

The constructor to a room takes two coordinates, x and y, and the constructor of a wall takes a direction inside a room. The constructor of a door takes two rooms and places itself between them.

Be careful when you construct the stable: the last added side in a direction in a room replaces the old side in that direction in that room. You can create different stables for different creational design patterns studied in this lab. Alternatively, you can use only one layout for all the patterns. In either way, your stable is required to have:

  1. two ordinary rooms with at least one door,
  2. five horseboxes with one boxdoor each,
  3. three rooms in a row that work like a corridor, and
  4. walls along the perimeter.

The Eclipse project for this lab can be set up in the same way as it was described with respect to the first lab.

Usage

  • Use the menu of the applet to switch between different construction methods.
  • Press the letter 'h' to add a horse into the stable.
  • Use the arrow keys to control the person represented by a helmet in the stable.
  • Press the enter key to open the door that is in front of the person.

Purpose

By creating the stable using different creational patterns, you observe the strengths and weaknesses of these patterns, and, in the future, you will be able to choose the one that fits best in a given situation.

Section A

Readings

The introduction to creational design patterns in GoF on p. 81–85, the Factory Method pattern starting from p. 107, and the lectures.

Instructions

Create a stable according to the requirements given earlier using the Factory Method pattern.

Write the body of the factoryConstruction method in StablePanel and create one or two your own classes.

Hints

Look at defaultConstruction in StablePanel to see how the classes representing various parts of a stable are utilized there.

Section B

Readings

The chapter about the Builder pattern in GoF on p. 97–107.

Instructions

Create a stable using the Builder pattern.

Write the body of the builderConstruction method in StablePanel and create one or two your own classes.

Hints

Stable is a singleton; adapt your Builder accordingly.

Section C

Readings

The chapter about the Prototype pattern in GoF on p. 117–126 and the lectures.

Instructions

Create a stable using the Prototype pattern. Inspect the requirements on a stable once again and decide on suitable prototypes.

Write the body of the builderConstruction method in StablePanel and create the class(es) needed for the Prototype pattern.

Hints

Think about how and who creates prototypes. Is a Singleton suitable for storing prototypes?

Hand In

Apart from explaining the details of your implementation and answering the questions of your lab assistant, you are required to hand in the classes that you have created and those that you have modified. To this end, provide your code with comments where it is needed, compress all the relevant classes (*.java only) into a single archive, and send this archive to the lab assistant.
